ext_descriptions.ext_description:
that provides a mathematical description of the properties of a system. In this part of ISO 10303 an Analytical_model includes the variable declarations of the mathematical description but may not include the assignment of actual values for the variables declared. Assignment of actual values is accomplished in This part of ISO 10303 provides support for computer systems to verify type consistency between product data defined in this part of ISO 10303 and product data captured by Analytical_models. This part of ISO 10303 describes the interfaces (ports) to an Analytical_model and provides support for type checking of the units used for the parameters that may be assigned values for an Analytical_model. Figure is an example of the case where actual values are not included: the Analytical_model for a resistor that is coded in pseudocode.
When the Analytical_model is referenced by an will be supplied for parameters declared in the interface and the simulator must ensure that types are compatible. Usually the system is exercised in experiments to evaluate the usefulness of the system in the intended application. The language syntax and semantics of an Analytical_model are not specified by this part of ISO 10303. This part of ISO 10303 provides complete support for exchange of units, including SI units, derived units, and user declared units. This part of ISO 10303 provides complete support for prefixes of units.

An Analytical_model_port_assignment is the relationship between a and an for the purpose of conducting analyses of the design. An Analytical_model_port_assignment binds or associates a behavioural representation to a structural representation. The cardinality or size of the Analytical_model_port shall be consistent with the cardinality or size of the terminal in the structural representation. This mechanism allows model ports and functional terminal definitionss to be associated regardless of their individual names.

the assigned_analytical_model_port specifies the role of the for the Analytical_model_port_assignment. <!-- This part of ISO 10303 does not constrain the type of Analytical_model_port that may participate in this relationship. However, this may be constrained in a future edition of this part of ISO 10303 to the type. -->

An Across_port_variable is a type of . An Across_port_variable maps a unit to an interface point for an and assigns an identifier to the mapping. This standard does not enumerate a fixed list of allowed "across unit". A unit is required. Physical macro level models require across variables to occur in pairs but that is not formalized in this standard. A temperature is an "across unit".
An Analog_analytical_model_port is a type of that defines an analog context. An analog context is a context where the domain values are not a discrete, enumerated set of values.

the signal_variable is an inverse relationship that specifies one or more upon which the Analog_analytical_model_port is existence dependent. A port may have more than one signal variable because so-called "through" and "across" variables are properties of the same analog port. Reference: http://icosym.cvut.cz/course/

An Analytical_representation is the association of specific data to properties of an in order to unambiguously characterize some behaviour of a real or imaginary object. The characterization may be considered to describe the behaviour exhibited by the model in a specific environment or for a range of environments for a specific experiment.
An Analytical_model_definition is a type of .
the associated_model_occurrence is an inverse relationship that specifies that the existence of the Analytical_model_definition is dependent on the existence of an to reference the .
An Analytical_model_make_from_relationship establishes a relationship between an analytical model selected for reuse and the new analytical model that results from the reuse.
the resultant_model specifies an that is the result of the reuse for the Analytical_model_make_from_relationship.
the reusable_model specifies an to be used for the Analytical_model_make_from_relationship.

An Analytical_model_parameter is a type of . An Analytical_model_parameter is a formally declared variable of the provided for an external application to populate at execution time in a computing environment. <!-- The base type of the variable is defined by the base type of the default_value or valid_range data.--> In Spice, temperature is a Analytical_model_parameter that may be set at the execution time.
the accessed_analytical_model is the analytical model for which the parameter is being established.

An Analytical_model_port may be an , or additionally may be a . An Analytical_model_port describes an interface point for an . These points are the points at which a simulator allows a user to stimulate an instance of an Analytical_model or to evaluate the response of an instance of an Analytical_model to a stimulus in an experiment. In this context, instance includes the reference to the Analytical_model and the literals required for the parameters. A simulator that enforces conservative laws enforces that the energy entering an instance of an Analytical_model must be the same as that leaving the instance of the Analytical_model. The structure of the port is not visible merely by accessing this information. The subtypes of this object provide more visibility into the underlying structure as appropriate. Members of the subtype tree of this object are populated as needed by an application in order to disclose the appropriate level of detail. The specialization in the subtypes of this object occur as a result of being more specific about certain properties of the port.

ext_description.note: The port_name is documented in the reference_document for the .

Containment in this case also explicitly states that the visibility of the name of an Analytical_model_port is limited to the that is the accessed_analytical_model.

An Analytical_model_scalar_port is a type of that has a size of exactly one. The Analytical_model_scalar_port is used if there is a requirement to specify the cardinality of the ports associated by a relationship entity. Some examples are in the allocation to a functional unit terminal definition for analysis, or in mapping between a distributed model and a lumped equivalent circuit model, or in mapping to a vector port specified in an external syntax.

An Analytical_model_vector_port is a type of that has a size greater than one. An Analytical_model_vector_port may be an . The Analytical_model_vector_port is used in the converse case to the . This part of ISO 10303 does not predefine the elements of a vector port. The cardinality of the structured port is known and a list of names is specified for it. Examples are bus ports, multi-degrees-of-freedom connections, microwave domain modes, and address and data bus definitions.
the size specifies the integer greater than one for the cardinality of the Analytical_model_vector_port.
A Digital_analytical_model_port is a type of that defines a digital context.
the port_type specifies the for the Digital_analytical_model_port. The port_type specifies one of a boolean_property_type, a logical_property_type, or a string_property_type for this .

the nominal_signal_flow_direction specifies the for the Digital_analytical_model_port. The nominal_signal_flow_direction specifies either BIDIRECTIONAL, INPUT_DIRECTION, OUTPUT_DIRECTION, or UNKNOWN_DIRECTION for the Digital_analytical_model_port.

A Port_variable may be a , or an , or a . A Port_variable maps a unit to an interface point for an and assigns an identifier to the mapping. When modeling physical systems at the macroscopic level, energy equations demand the ability to specify a through variable and an across variable for the same port.

the unit_of_measure specifies the string for the descriptive label for the unit of measure of the value of a property associated with the simulated physical phenomenon exchanged through a member of the Port_variable. The unit_of_measure need not be specified for a particular Port_variable. The representation of the unit_of_measure is in accordance with ISO 10303-41.

ext_description.note: The variable_name is documented in the reference_document for the .

A Terminal_pair_port_equivalence_relationship is the assignment association between a pair of scalar ports and a single distributed port.

ext_description.p: the scalar_ports specify the two in the ordered sequence for the Terminal_pair_port_equivalence_relationship. The second scalar_port is always the reference port. Other details depend on the specific domain of the .
ext_description.example: Port "INPUT" of a microwave coaxial filter model is the equivalent_port for this example. Port "INPUT center pin" is the first Analytical_model_scalar_port for this example. Port "INPUT shield" is the second Analytical_model_scalar_port for this example.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the equivalent_port specifies the that represents the single distributed port for the Terminal_pair_port_equivalence_relationship.

A Through_port_variable is a type of . A Through_port_variable maps a unit that is identified as a "through unit" to an interface point for an and assigns an identifier to the mapping. This standard does not enumerate a fixed list of allowed "through unit". A unit is required. An electric_current_unit is a "through unit". A temperature is an "across unit". Reference: ISO 10303-41

A Transform_port_variable is a type of . A Transform_port_variable may map a unit to an interface point for an . This standard does not enumerate a fixed list of allowed "transform unit". A Laplace transform based would use a Transform_port_variable as the for input and output ports.
the nominal_signal_flow_direction specifies either INPUT_DIRECTION, OUTPUT_DIRECTION, or UNKNOWN_DIRECTION for the Transform_port_variable.
